lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read and understand a text containing the units' target language.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Before reading, write 3–4 key vocabulary items from recent units on the board. Students scan the text and circle the words they find.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify the units' target language correctly.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play short chunks of the review audio. After each, ask: “What word did you hear?” Students point to matching picture or write it down.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can reflect on their learning across the units and say what they can do.
supportStrategies: (Reflection) Draw a mind map on the board with topics (e.g., food, transport, school). Students suggest words or sentences they remember for each.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.
VYL: many words starting in sibilants prove extremely difficult (shirt, shorts, socks, shoes). Plurals for singular items (trousers, shorts)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
